displaytitle: Roundel with Intaglio Reliefs of St. Thekla
creditline: Gift of the Committee for the Excavation of Antioch to Princeton University

titles.title: Roundel with Intaglio Reliefs of St. Thekla

texts.textentryhtml:
This roundel’s remarkable design uses an established Roman format to illustrate new Christian ideas: the hole on the rim suggests it was suspended on a cord and perhaps rotated like Roman cultic discs known as oscilla. Its face depicts the preeminent female saint of Late Antiquity, Thekla, whose pilgrimage site was not far from the roundel’s findspot in Daphne. Thekla extends her arms in prayer as fearsome animals, including a lunging bear, surround her during her trials in the amphitheater. The roundel’s reverse side shows a jeweled cross. Turning the object, by hand or in the breeze, visually superimposed Thekla onto the cross, enacting her martyrial embrace of suffering and linking her endurance to the model of Christ’s Passion. Reflecting on the way motion could have activated this roundel illustrated for me the importance of considering ancient objects not as isolated images but as sites of interactive, multisensory experiences.

Katie Taronas, Postdoctoral Fellow in Ancient Mediterranean Religions, University of Texas at Austin
Excavated by the Princeton-led team at Antioch-on-the-Orontes, present-day Antakya, Turkey, 1931-1939; with the Museum since 1939
texts.remarks: Batch edit for Provenance publication project
